Zend_Http  
Client  
Zend_Http_Client_Exception  
Implement proxy settings  
No 
No 

Description

Zend_Http_Client is an implementation of an HTTP client in PHP. The client supports basic features like sending different HTTP requests and handling redirections, as well as more advanced features like proxy settings, HTTP authentication and cookie persistence (using a Zend_Http_CookieJar object)

Methods

__construct, _detectFileMimeType, _flattenParametersArray, _getParametersRecursive, _openTempStream, _prepareBody, _prepareHeaders, _setParameter, encodeAuthHeader, encodeFormData, getAdapter, getCookieJar, getHeader, getLastRequest, getLastResponse, getRedirectionsCount, getStream, getUri, request, resetParameters, setAdapter, setAuth, setConfig, setCookie, setCookieJar, setEncType, setFileUpload, setHeaders, setMethod, setParameterGet, setParameterPost, setRawData, setStream, setUri,

_detectFileMimeType( string   $file, ) : string

Description

Attempt to detect the MIME type of a file using available extensions

This method will try to detect the MIME type of a file. If the fileinfo extension is available, it will be used. If not, the mime_magic extension which is deprected but is still available in many PHP setups will be tried.

If neither extension is available, the default application/octet-stream MIME type will be returned


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$file string | File path

Return value

Type Description
string MIME type

_flattenParametersArray( array   $parray, string   $prefix = null, ) : array

Description

Convert an array of parameters into a flat array of (key, value) pairs

Will flatten a potentially multi-dimentional array of parameters (such as POST parameters) into a flat array of (key, value) paris. In case of multi-dimentional arrays, square brackets ([]) will be added to the key to indicate an array.


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$parray array |
$prefix string | null

Return value

Type Description
array

Tags

Name Description
since 1.9

_getParametersRecursive( array   $parray, bool   $urlencode = false, ) : array

Description

Helper method that gets a possibly multi-level parameters array (get or post) and flattens it.

The method returns an array of (key, value) pairs (because keys are not necessarily unique. If one of the parameters in as array, it will also add a [] suffix to the key.

This method is deprecated since Zend Framework 1.9 in favour of self::_flattenParametersArray() and will be dropped in 2.0


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$parray array | The parameters array
$urlencode bool | Whether to urlencode the name and value false

Return value

Type Description
array

Tags

Name Description
deprecated since 1.9

resetParameters( bool   $clearAll = false, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Clear all GET and POST parameters

Should be used to reset the request parameters if the client is used for several concurrent requests.

clearAll parameter controls if we clean just parameters or also headers and last_*


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$clearAll bool | Should all data be cleared? false

Return value

Type Description
Zend_Http_Client

setAuth( string|false   $user, string   $password, string   $type = self, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set HTTP authentication parameters

$type should be one of the supported types - see the self::AUTH_* constants.

To enable authentication: $this->setAuth('shahar', 'secret', Zend_Http_Client::AUTH_BASIC);

To disable authentication: $this->setAuth(false);


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$user string | false | User name or false disable authentication
$password string | Password
$type string | Authentication type self

Return value

Type Description
Zend_Http_Client

Tags

Name Description
see http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc2617.html
throws Zend_Http_Client_Exception

setCookieJar( Zend_Http_CookieJar|boolean   $cookiejar = true, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set the HTTP client's cookie jar.

A cookie jar is an object that holds and maintains cookies across HTTP requests and responses.


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$cookiejar Zend_Http_CookieJar | boolean | Existing cookiejar object, true to create a new one, false to disable true

setFileUpload( string   $filename, string   $formname, string   $data = null, string   $ctype = null, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set a file to upload (using a POST request)

Can be used in two ways:

  1. $data is null (default): $filename is treated as the name if a local file which will be read and sent. Will try to guess the content type using mime_content_type().
  2. $data is set - $filename is sent as the file name, but $data is sent as the file contents and no file is read from the file system. In this case, you need to manually set the Content-Type ($ctype) or it will default to application/octet-stream.

Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$filename string | Name of file to upload, or name to save as
$formname string | Name of form element to send as
$data string | Data to send (if null, $filename is read and sent) null
$ctype string | Content type to use (if $data is set and $ctype is null, will be application/octet-stream) null

Return value

Type Description
Zend_Http_Client

Tags

Name Description
throws Zend_Http_Client_Exception

setHeaders( string|array   $name, mixed   $value = null, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set one or more request headers

This function can be used in several ways to set the client's request headers: 1. By providing two parameters: $name as the header to set (e.g. 'Host') and $value as it's value (e.g. 'www.example.com'). 2. By providing a single header string as the only parameter e.g. 'Host: www.example.com' 3. By providing an array of headers as the first parameter e.g. array('host' => 'www.example.com', 'x-foo: bar'). In This case the function will call itself recursively for each array item.


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$name string | array | Header name, full header string ('Header: value') or an array of headers
$value mixed | Header value or null null

Return value

Type Description
Zend_Http_Client

Tags

Name Description
throws Zend_Http_Client_Exception

setMethod( string   $method = self, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set the next request's method

Validated the passed method and sets it. If we have files set for POST requests, and the new method is not POST, the files are silently dropped.


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$method string | self

Return value

setRawData( string|resource   $data, string   $enctype = null, ) : Zend_Http_Client

Description

Set the raw (already encoded) POST data.

This function is here for two reasons: 1. For advanced user who would like to set their own data, already encoded 2. For backwards compatibilty: If someone uses the old post($data) method. this method will be used to set the encoded data.

$data can also be stream (such as file) from which the data will be read.


Arguments

Name Type Description Default
$data string | resource |
$enctype string | null

Return value

Type Description
Zend_Http_Client

Fileinfo magic database resourceresource
<p>This variable is populated the first time _detectFileMimeType is called and is then reused on every call to this method</p>

  protected  $adapter = null

The adapter used to perform the actual connection to the serverZend_Http_Client_Adapter_Interface


  protected  $auth =

HTTP Authentication settingsarray|null
<p>Expected to be an associative array with this structure: $this->auth = array('user' => 'username', 'password' => 'password', 'type' => 'basic') Where 'type' should be one of the supported authentication types (see the AUTH_* constants), for example 'basic' or 'digest'.</p> <p>If null, no authentication will be used.</p>
